conclusion: Need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph to determine variable linear motion.
The graph shows velocity on the y-axis and time on the x-axis; velocity in m/s and time in seconds.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s indicating uniform motion.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s indicating deceleration.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s indicating acceleration in the opposite direction.
Variable linear motion means the velocity is changing over time.
In the first 3 seconds, velocity is constant from t = 0 to t = 1 second, but changes from t = 1 to t = 3 seconds.
The particle undergoes variable linear motion from t = 1 to t = 3 seconds.
Yes, the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds.
